segment.source: The media player is used to view and listen to video, audio, and images.
segment.target: The media player is used to view and listen to video, audio, and images.

segment.source: Media player
segment.target: Media player

segment.source: Media player
segment.target: Media player

segment.source: The media player is used to view and listen to video, audio, and images.
segment.target: The media player is used to view and listen to video, audio, and images.

segment.source: Media playback can be inline (embedded in a page or with a group of other controls) or in a dedicated full-screen view.
segment.target: Media playback can be inline (embedded in a page or with a group of other controls) or in a dedicated full-screen view.

segment.source: You can modify the player's button set, change the background of the control bar, and arrange layouts as you see fit.
segment.target: You can modify the player's button set, change the background of the control bar, and arrange layouts as you see fit.

segment.source: Just keep in mind that users expect a basic control set (play/pause, skip back, skip forward).
segment.target: Just keep in mind that users expect a basic control set (play/pause, skip back, skip forward).

segment.source: Media element with transport controls
segment.target: Media element with transport controls

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: MediaElement class
segment.target: MediaElement class

segment.source: MediaTransportControls class
segment.target: MediaTransportControls class

segment.source: Is this the right control?
segment.target: Is this the right control?

segment.source: Use a media player when you want to play audio or video in your app.
segment.target: Use a media player when you want to play audio or video in your app.

segment.source: To display a collection of images, use a Flip view.
segment.target: To display a collection of images, use a Flip view.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: A media element in the Windows 10 Get Started app.
segment.target: A media element in the Windows 10 Get Started app.

segment.source: A media elementin the Windows 10 Get Started app
segment.target: A media elementin the Windows 10 Get Started app

segment.source: Create a media player
segment.target: Create a media player

segment.source: Add media to your app by creating a MediaElement object in XAML and set the Source to a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) that points to an audio or video file.
segment.target: Add media to your app by creating a MediaElement object in XAML and set the Source to a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) that points to an audio or video file.

segment.source: This XAML creates a MediaElement and sets its Source property to the URI of a video file that's local to the app.
segment.target: This XAML creates a MediaElement and sets its Source property to the URI of a video file that's local to the app.

segment.source: The MediaElement begins playing when the page loads.
segment.target: The MediaElement begins playing when the page loads.

segment.source: To suppress media from starting right away, you can set the AutoPlay property to false.
segment.target: To suppress media from starting right away, you can set the AutoPlay property to false.

segment.source: This XAML creates a MediaElement with the built in transport controls enabled and the AutoPlay property set to false.
segment.target: This XAML creates a MediaElement with the built in transport controls enabled and the AutoPlay property set to false.

segment.source: Media transport controls
segment.target: Media transport controls

segment.source: MediaElement has built in transport controls that handle play, stop, pause, volume, mute, seeking/progress, and audio track selection.
segment.target: MediaElement has built in transport controls that handle play, stop, pause, volume, mute, seeking/progress, and audio track selection.

segment.source: To enable these controls, set AreTransportControlsEnabled to true.
segment.target: To enable these controls, set AreTransportControlsEnabled to true.

segment.source: To disable them, set AreTransportControlsEnabled to false.
segment.target: To disable them, set AreTransportControlsEnabled to false.

segment.source: The transport controls are represented by the MediaTransportControls class.
segment.target: The transport controls are represented by the MediaTransportControls class.

segment.source: You can use the transport controls as-is, or customize them in various ways.
segment.target: You can use the transport controls as-is, or customize them in various ways.

segment.source: For more info, see the MediaTransportControls class reference and Create custom transport controls.
segment.target: For more info, see the MediaTransportControls class reference and Create custom transport controls.

segment.source: The transport controls let the user control most aspects of the MediaElement, but the MediaElement also provides numerous properties and methods that you can use to control audio and video playback.
segment.target: The transport controls let the user control most aspects of the MediaElement, but the MediaElement also provides numerous properties and methods that you can use to control audio and video playback.

segment.source: For more info, see the Control MediaElement programmatically section later in this article.
segment.target: For more info, see the Control MediaElement programmatically section later in this article.

segment.source: The transport controls support single- and double-row layouts.
segment.target: The transport controls support single- and double-row layouts.

segment.source: The first example here is a single-row layout, with the play/pause button located to the left of the media timeline.
segment.target: The first example here is a single-row layout, with the play/pause button located to the left of the media timeline.

segment.source: This layout is best reserved for compact screens.
segment.target: This layout is best reserved for compact screens.

segment.source: Example of MTC controls on phone, single row
segment.target: Example of MTC controls on phone, single row

segment.source: The double-row controls layout (below) is recommended for most usage scenarios, especially on larger screens.
segment.target: The double-row controls layout (below) is recommended for most usage scenarios, especially on larger screens.

segment.source: This layout provides more space for controls and makes the timeline easier for the user to operate.
segment.target: This layout provides more space for controls and makes the timeline easier for the user to operate.

segment.source: Example of MTC controls on phone, double row
segment.target: Example of MTC controls on phone, double row

segment.source: System media transport controls
segment.target: System media transport controls

segment.source: You can also integrate MediaElement with the system media transport controls.
segment.target: You can also integrate MediaElement with the system media transport controls.

segment.source: The system transport controls are the controls that pop up when hardware media keys are pressed, such as the media buttons on keyboards.
segment.target: The system transport controls are the controls that pop up when hardware media keys are pressed, such as the media buttons on keyboards.

segment.source: If the user presses the pause key on a keyboard and your app supports the SystemMediaTransportControls, your app is notified and you can take the appropriate action.
segment.target: If the user presses the pause key on a keyboard and your app supports the SystemMediaTransportControls, your app is notified and you can take the appropriate action.

segment.source: For more info, see System Media Transport Controls.
segment.target: For more info, see System Media Transport Controls.

segment.source: Set the media source
segment.target: Set the media source

segment.source: To play files on the network or files embedded with the app, set the Source property to the path of the file.
segment.target: To play files on the network or files embedded with the app, set the Source property to the path of the file.

segment.source: Tip To open files from the internet, you need to declare the Internet (Client) capability in your app's manifest (Package.appxmanifest).
segment.target: Tip To open files from the internet, you need to declare the Internet (Client) capability in your app's manifest (Package.appxmanifest).

segment.source: For more info about declaring capabilities, see App capability declarations.
segment.target: For more info about declaring capabilities, see App capability declarations.

segment.source: This code attempts to set the Source property of the MediaElement defined in XAML to the path of a file entered into a TextBox.
segment.target: This code attempts to set the Source property of the MediaElement defined in XAML to the path of a file entered into a TextBox.

segment.source: To set the media source to a media file embedded in the app, create a Uri with the path prefixed with ms-appx:/// and then set the Source to it.
segment.target: To set the media source to a media file embedded in the app, create a Uri with the path prefixed with ms-appx:/// and then set the Source to it.

segment.source: For example, for a file called video1.mp4 that is in a Videos subfolder, the path would look like: ms-appx:///Videos/video1.mp4
segment.target: For example, for a file called video1.mp4 that is in a Videos subfolder, the path would look like: ms-appx:///Videos/video1.mp4

segment.source: This code sets the Source property of the MediaElement defined previously in XAML to ms-appx:///Videos/video1.mp4.
segment.target: This code sets the Source property of the MediaElement defined previously in XAML to ms-appx:///Videos/video1.mp4.

segment.source: Open local media files
segment.target: Open local media files

segment.source: To open files on the local system or from OneDrive, you can use the FileOpenPicker to get the file and SetSource to set the media source, or you can programmatically access the user media folders.
segment.target: To open files on the local system or from OneDrive, you can use the FileOpenPicker to get the file and SetSource to set the media source, or you can programmatically access the user media folders.

segment.source: If your app needs access without user interaction to the Music or Video folders, for example, if you are enumerating all the music or video files in the user's collection and displaying them in your app, then you need to declare the Music Library and Video Library capabilities.
segment.target: If your app needs access without user interaction to the Music or Video folders, for example, if you are enumerating all the music or video files in the user's collection and displaying them in your app, then you need to declare the Music Library and Video Library capabilities.

segment.source: For more info, see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.
segment.target: For more info, see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.

segment.source: The FileOpenPicker does not require special capabilities to access files on the local file system, such as the user's Music or Video folders, since the user has complete control over which file is being accessed.
segment.target: The FileOpenPicker does not require special capabilities to access files on the local file system, such as the user's Music or Video folders, since the user has complete control over which file is being accessed.

segment.source: From a security and privacy standpoint, it is best to minimize the number of capabilities your app uses.
segment.target: From a security and privacy standpoint, it is best to minimize the number of capabilities your app uses.

segment.source: To open local media using FileOpenPicker
segment.target: To open local media using FileOpenPicker

segment.source: Call FileOpenPicker to let the user pick a media file.
segment.target: Call FileOpenPicker to let the user pick a media file.

segment.source: Use the FileOpenPicker class to select a media file.
segment.target: Use the FileOpenPicker class to select a media file.

segment.source: Set the FileTypeFilter to specify which file types the FileOpenPicker displays.
segment.target: Set the FileTypeFilter to specify which file types the FileOpenPicker displays.

segment.source: Call PickSingleFileAsync to launch the file picker and get the file.
segment.target: Call PickSingleFileAsync to launch the file picker and get the file.

segment.source: Call SetSource to set the chosen media file as the MediaElement.Source.
segment.target: Call SetSource to set the chosen media file as the MediaElement.Source.

segment.source: To set the Source of the MediaElement to the StorageFile returned from the FileOpenPicker, you need to open a stream.
segment.target: To set the Source of the MediaElement to the StorageFile returned from the FileOpenPicker, you need to open a stream.

segment.source: Call the OpenAsync method on the StorageFile, which returns a stream that you can pass into the MediaElement.SetSource method.
segment.target: Call the OpenAsync method on the StorageFile, which returns a stream that you can pass into the MediaElement.SetSource method.

segment.source: Then call Play on the MediaElement to start the media.
segment.target: Then call Play on the MediaElement to start the media.

segment.source: This example shows how to use the FileOpenPicker to choose a file and set the file as the Source of a MediaElement.
segment.target: This example shows how to use the FileOpenPicker to choose a file and set the file as the Source of a MediaElement.

segment.source: Set the poster source
segment.target: Set the poster source

segment.source: You can use the PosterSource property to provide your MediaElement with a visual representation before the media is loaded.
segment.target: You can use the PosterSource property to provide your MediaElement with a visual representation before the media is loaded.

segment.source: A PosterSource is an image, such as a screen shot or movie poster, that is displayed in place of the media.
segment.target: A PosterSource is an image, such as a screen shot or movie poster, that is displayed in place of the media.

segment.source: The PosterSource is displayed in the following situations:
segment.target: The PosterSource is displayed in the following situations:

segment.source: When a valid source is not set.
segment.target: When a valid source is not set.

segment.source: For example, Source is not set, Source was set to Null, or the source is invalid (as is the case when a MediaFailed event occurs).
segment.target: For example, Source is not set, Source was set to Null, or the source is invalid (as is the case when a MediaFailed event occurs).

segment.source: While media is loading.
segment.target: While media is loading.

segment.source: For example, a valid source is set, but the MediaOpened event has not occurred yet.
segment.target: For example, a valid source is set, but the MediaOpened event has not occurred yet.

segment.source: When media is streaming to another device.
segment.target: When media is streaming to another device.

segment.source: When the media is audio only.
segment.target: When the media is audio only.

segment.source: Here's a MediaElement with its Source set to an album track, and it's PosterSource set to an image of the album cover.
segment.target: Here's a MediaElement with its Source set to an album track, and it's PosterSource set to an image of the album cover.

segment.source: Keep the device's screen active
segment.target: Keep the device's screen active

segment.source: Typically, a device dims the display (and eventually turns it off) to save battery life when the user is away, but video apps need to keep the screen on so the user can see the video.
segment.target: Typically, a device dims the display (and eventually turns it off) to save battery life when the user is away, but video apps need to keep the screen on so the user can see the video.

segment.source: To prevent the display from being deactivated when user action is no longer detected, such as when an app is playing full-screen video, you can call DisplayRequest.RequestActive.
segment.target: To prevent the display from being deactivated when user action is no longer detected, such as when an app is playing full-screen video, you can call DisplayRequest.RequestActive.

segment.source: The DisplayRequest class lets you tell Windows to keep the display turned on so the user can see the video.
segment.target: The DisplayRequest class lets you tell Windows to keep the display turned on so the user can see the video.

segment.source: To conserve power and battery life, you should call DisplayRequest.RequestRelease to release the display request when it is no longer required.
segment.target: To conserve power and battery life, you should call DisplayRequest.RequestRelease to release the display request when it is no longer required.

segment.source: Windows automatically deactivates your app's active display requests when your app moves off screen, and re-activates them when your app comes back to the foreground.
segment.target: Windows automatically deactivates your app's active display requests when your app moves off screen, and re-activates them when your app comes back to the foreground.

segment.source: Here are some situations when you should release the display request:
segment.target: Here are some situations when you should release the display request:

segment.source: Video playback is paused, for example, by user action, buffering, or adjustment due to limited bandwidth.
segment.target: Video playback is paused, for example, by user action, buffering, or adjustment due to limited bandwidth.

segment.source: Playback stops.
segment.target: Playback stops.

segment.source: For example, the video is done playing or the presentation is over.
segment.target: For example, the video is done playing or the presentation is over.

segment.source: A playback error has occurred.
segment.target: A playback error has occurred.

segment.source: For example, network connectivity issues or a corrupted file.
segment.target: For example, network connectivity issues or a corrupted file.

segment.source: To keep the screen active
segment.target: To keep the screen active

segment.source: Create a global DisplayRequest variable.
segment.target: Create a global DisplayRequest variable.

segment.source: Initialize it to null.
segment.target: Initialize it to null.

segment.source: Call RequestActive to notify Windows that the app requires the display to remain on.
segment.target: Call RequestActive to notify Windows that the app requires the display to remain on.

segment.source: Call RequestRelease to release the display request whenever video playback is stopped, paused, or interrupted by a playback error.
segment.target: Call RequestRelease to release the display request whenever video playback is stopped, paused, or interrupted by a playback error.

segment.source: When your app no longer has any active display requests, Windows saves battery life by dimming the display (and eventually turning it off) when the device is not being used.
segment.target: When your app no longer has any active display requests, Windows saves battery life by dimming the display (and eventually turning it off) when the device is not being used.

segment.source: Here, you use the CurrentStateChanged event to detect these situations.
segment.target: Here, you use the CurrentStateChanged event to detect these situations.

segment.source: Then, use the IsAudioOnly property to determine whether an audio or video file is playing, and keep the screen active only if video is playing.
segment.target: Then, use the IsAudioOnly property to determine whether an audio or video file is playing, and keep the screen active only if video is playing.

segment.source: Control the media player programmatically
segment.target: Control the media player programmatically

segment.source: MediaElement provides numerous properties, methods, and events for controlling audio and video playback.
segment.target: MediaElement provides numerous properties, methods, and events for controlling audio and video playback.

segment.source: For a full listing of properties, methods, and events, see the MediaElement reference page.
segment.target: For a full listing of properties, methods, and events, see the MediaElement reference page.

segment.source: Select audio tracks in different languages
segment.target: Select audio tracks in different languages

segment.source: Use the AudioStreamIndex property and the GetAudioStreamLanguage method to change the audio to a different language track on a video.
segment.target: Use the AudioStreamIndex property and the GetAudioStreamLanguage method to change the audio to a different language track on a video.

segment.source: Videos can also contain multiple audio tracks in the same language, such as director commentaries on films.
segment.target: Videos can also contain multiple audio tracks in the same language, such as director commentaries on films.

segment.source: This example specifically shows how to switch between different languages, but you can modify this code to switch between any audio tracks.
segment.target: This example specifically shows how to switch between different languages, but you can modify this code to switch between any audio tracks.

segment.source: To select audio tracks in different languages
segment.target: To select audio tracks in different languages

segment.source: Get the audio tracks.
segment.target: Get the audio tracks.

segment.source: To search for a track in a specific language, start by iterating through each audio track on the video.
segment.target: To search for a track in a specific language, start by iterating through each audio track on the video.

segment.source: Use AudioStreamCount as the max value for a for loop.
segment.target: Use AudioStreamCount as the max value for a for loop.

segment.source: Get the language of the audio track.
segment.target: Get the language of the audio track.

segment.source: Use the GetAudioStreamLanguage method to get the language of the track.
segment.target: Use the GetAudioStreamLanguage method to get the language of the track.

segment.source: The language of the track is identified by a language code, such as "en" for English or "ja" for Japanese.
segment.target: The language of the track is identified by a language code, such as "en" for English or "ja" for Japanese.

segment.source: Set the active audio track.
segment.target: Set the active audio track.

segment.source: When you find the track with the desired language, set the AudioStreamIndex to the index of the track.
segment.target: When you find the track with the desired language, set the AudioStreamIndex to the index of the track.

segment.source: Setting AudioStreamIndex to null selects the default audio track, which is defined by the content.
segment.target: Setting AudioStreamIndex to null selects the default audio track, which is defined by the content.

segment.source: Here's some code that attempts to set the audio track to the specified language.
segment.target: Here's some code that attempts to set the audio track to the specified language.

segment.source: It iterates through the audio tracks on a MediaElement object and uses GetAudioStreamLanguage to get the language of each track.
segment.target: It iterates through the audio tracks on a MediaElement object and uses GetAudioStreamLanguage to get the language of each track.

segment.source: If the desired language track exists, the AudioStreamIndex is set to the index of that track.
segment.target: If the desired language track exists, the AudioStreamIndex is set to the index of that track.

segment.source: Enable full window video rendering
segment.target: Enable full window video rendering

segment.source: Set the IsFullWindow property to enable and disable full window rendering.
segment.target: Set the IsFullWindow property to enable and disable full window rendering.

segment.source: When you programmatically set full window rendering in your app, you should always use IsFullWindow instead of doing it manually.
segment.target: When you programmatically set full window rendering in your app, you should always use IsFullWindow instead of doing it manually.

segment.source: IsFullWindow insures that system level optimizations are performed that improve performance and battery life.
segment.target: IsFullWindow insures that system level optimizations are performed that improve performance and battery life.

segment.source: If full window rendering is not set up correctly, these optimizations may not be enabled.
segment.target: If full window rendering is not set up correctly, these optimizations may not be enabled.

segment.source: Here is some code that creates an AppBarButton that toggles full window rendering.
segment.target: Here is some code that creates an AppBarButton that toggles full window rendering.

segment.source: Resize and stretch video
segment.target: Resize and stretch video

segment.source: Use the Stretch property to change how the video content fills the container it's in.
segment.target: Use the Stretch property to change how the video content fills the container it's in.

segment.source: This resizes and stretches the video depending on the Stretch value.
segment.target: This resizes and stretches the video depending on the Stretch value.

segment.source: The Stretch states are similar to picture size settings on many TV sets.
segment.target: The Stretch states are similar to picture size settings on many TV sets.

segment.source: You can hook this up to a button and allow the user to choose which setting they prefer.
segment.target: You can hook this up to a button and allow the user to choose which setting they prefer.

segment.source: None displays the native resolution of the content in its original size.
segment.target: None displays the native resolution of the content in its original size.

segment.source: Uniform fills up as much of the space as possible while preserving the aspect ratio and the image content.
segment.target: Uniform fills up as much of the space as possible while preserving the aspect ratio and the image content.

segment.source: This can result in horizontal or vertical black bars at the edges of the video.
segment.target: This can result in horizontal or vertical black bars at the edges of the video.

segment.source: This is similar to wide-screen modes.
segment.target: This is similar to wide-screen modes.

segment.source: UniformToFill fills up the entire space while preserving the aspect ratio.
segment.target: UniformToFill fills up the entire space while preserving the aspect ratio.

segment.source: This can result in some of the image being cropped.
segment.target: This can result in some of the image being cropped.

segment.source: This is similar to full-screen modes.
segment.target: This is similar to full-screen modes.

segment.source: Fill fills up the entire space, but does not preserve the aspect ratio.
segment.target: Fill fills up the entire space, but does not preserve the aspect ratio.

segment.source: None of image is cropped, but stretching may occur.
segment.target: None of image is cropped, but stretching may occur.

segment.source: This is similar to stretch modes.
segment.target: This is similar to stretch modes.

segment.source: Stretch enumeration values Here, an AppBarButton is used to cycle through the Stretch options.
segment.target: Stretch enumeration values Here, an AppBarButton is used to cycle through the Stretch options.

segment.source: A switch statement checks the current state of the Stretch property and sets it to the next value in the Stretch enumeration.
segment.target: A switch statement checks the current state of the Stretch property and sets it to the next value in the Stretch enumeration.

segment.source: This lets the user cycle through the different stretch states.
segment.target: This lets the user cycle through the different stretch states.

segment.source: Enable low-latency playback
segment.target: Enable low-latency playback

segment.source: Set the RealTimePlayback property to true on a MediaElement to enable the media element to reduce the initial latency for playback.
segment.target: Set the RealTimePlayback property to true on a MediaElement to enable the media element to reduce the initial latency for playback.

segment.source: This is critical for two-way communications apps, and can be applicable to some gaming scenarios.
segment.target: This is critical for two-way communications apps, and can be applicable to some gaming scenarios.

segment.source: Be aware that this mode is more resource intensive and less power-efficient.
segment.target: Be aware that this mode is more resource intensive and less power-efficient.

segment.source: This example creates a MediaElement and sets RealTimePlayback to true.
segment.target: This example creates a MediaElement and sets RealTimePlayback to true.

segment.source: Recommendations
segment.target: Recommendations

segment.source: The media player comes in a dark theme and a light theme, but opt for the dark theme in most situations.
segment.target: The media player comes in a dark theme and a light theme, but opt for the dark theme in most situations.

segment.source: The dark background provides better contrast, in particular for low-light conditions, and limits the control bar from interfering in the viewing experience.
segment.target: The dark background provides better contrast, in particular for low-light conditions, and limits the control bar from interfering in the viewing experience.

segment.source: Encourage a dedicated viewing experience by promoting full-screen mode over inline mode.
segment.target: Encourage a dedicated viewing experience by promoting full-screen mode over inline mode.

segment.source: The full-screen viewing experience is optimal, and options are restricted in the inline mode.
segment.target: The full-screen viewing experience is optimal, and options are restricted in the inline mode.

segment.source: If you have the screen real estate, go with the double-row layout.
segment.target: If you have the screen real estate, go with the double-row layout.

segment.source: It provides more space for controls than the compact single-row layout.
segment.target: It provides more space for controls than the compact single-row layout.

segment.source: Add whatever custom options you need to the media player to provide the best experience for your app, but keep in mind the following:
segment.target: Add whatever custom options you need to the media player to provide the best experience for your app, but keep in mind the following:

segment.source: Limit the customization of the default controls, which have been optimized for the media playback experience.
segment.target: Limit the customization of the default controls, which have been optimized for the media playback experience.

segment.source: On phones and other mobile devices, the device chrome remains black, but on laptops and desktops, the device chrome inherits the user's theme color.
segment.target: On phones and other mobile devices, the device chrome remains black, but on laptops and desktops, the device chrome inherits the user's theme color.

segment.source: Try not to overload the control bar with too many options.
segment.target: Try not to overload the control bar with too many options.

segment.source: Don't shrink the media timeline below its default minimum size, which will severely limit its effectiveness.
segment.target: Don't shrink the media timeline below its default minimum size, which will severely limit its effectiveness.

segment.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.
segment.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
segment.target: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
